Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2 Consortium: Development of Forward-Angle Tracking Telescopes for Luminosity Monitoring at OLYMPUS
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

This award will enable Hampton University, under the leadership of PI Dr. Michael Kohl, to construct and implement luminosity monitors for the so-called OLYMPUS experiment. The OLYMPUS experiment (pOsitron-proton and eLectron-proton elastic scattering to test the hYpothesis of Multi-Photon exchange Using doriS) at DESY Laboratory, Germany, will be carried out in a multi-national collaboration. This experiment will provide definitive information about how electrons interact with protons and neutrons, thereby settling key uncertainties surrounding other electron scattering experiments. The luminosity monitors will be built in close collaboration with Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). Dr. Kohl is one of the originators of OLYMPUS and is pursuing it in a lead role as co-spokesperson along with co-PIs Dr. Richard Milner and Dr. Douglas Hasell from MIT. The luminosity monitors are considered essential in the overall OLYMPUS setup to warrant the small anticipated systematic uncertainties and are the responsibility of Dr. Kohl's group.

This MRI-R2 project enables new research and educational opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students from minority populations, predominantly African-Americans. This MRI-R2 will allow construction and testing of the instrument in a new lab on the campus of Hampton University, in a newly constructed research building. The active role of students and young researchers integrated in the OLYMPUS collaboration prepares and trains them very effectively in their future role as globally engaged scientists. In particular, attracting undergraduate students to this program serves the underlying purpose of providing a pipeline of talented undergraduate students towards graduate education in top schools and to ultimately increase the number of underrepresented, in particular African-American, PhDs, which is at the heart of Hampton University's mission.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the funding from this grant, PI Dr. Kohl and his group at Hampton University (see Figure 1) have been enabled to develop, construct, commission and operate a set of novel Gas Electron Multiplier (GEM) tracking detectors for the OLYMPUS experiment at DESY in Hamburg, Germany. The detectors were constructed at Hampton University in 2010-2011 and then transferred to DESY for installation in the OLYMPUS setup. The OLYMPUS experiment (shown in Figure 2) has been prepared from 2010-2012 to compare the positron-proton and electron-proton scattering probabilities with high precision, which constitutes a stringent and quantitative test of the hypothesis that the electron-proton interaction occasionally requires the exchange of two instead of one photon, which is usually assumed. Two tracking telescopes each consisting of three GEM elements and three wire chambers (MWPC) have been constructed (shown in Figure 3) and served to measure the rates of forward-angle elastic scattering in order to monitor the intensities of the OLYMPUS experiment over time and between the electron and positron beam species. Operation of the GEM detectors has been very stable, the efficiency of each element was found to be close to 100%, and the locations of the charged tracks could be determined with a resolution of 70 micrometers. Data taking of OLYMPUS has been completed end of 2012, the analysis of the collected data is now underway. The GEM detectors have performed so well that PI Dr. Kohl decided to utilize them in another, new project, the Muon Scattering Experiment (MUSE) at the Paul-Scherrer Institute (PSI) in Switzerland. The MUSE experiment has been proposed to compare muon-proton and electron-proton elastic scattering to shed light on the so-called proton radius puzzle. At MUSE, the former OLYMPUS GEM telescopes are used to provide a 3D beam tomography by tracking the secondary beam at PSI composed of muons, pions, and electrons of either charge particle-by-particle.
